channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [OOZIE-3083] Make improved version Info backward compatible
item.description:
OOZIE-2004 changed the format of the version info output considerably.
We should change it back to a more compatible format.

It could be something like

{"buildVersion":"5.0.0-SNAPSHOT", "buildInfo":"{build.time=${build.time}, vc.url=${vc.url}, build.user=asasvari, vc.revision=${vc.revision}"}
item.summary: Make improved version Info backward compatible

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Thanks for picking this up dbist13! Will you have the time to work on this soon? OOZIE-2004 is breaking some of our internal integration tests and we would like to fix them quickly.
gezapeti I don't want to be a bottleneck, I reassigned as I don't know my availability. Thank you for understanding.
Thanks for the quick response! I'll take care of this one
I've decided to keep the new format and add the old one back as well.

Thanks gezapeti!
+1 pending on your confirmation that UI shows the correct version. In that case, we can safely resolve OOZIE-3152 and include this one for 5.0.0-beta1.

gezapeti I applied the patch, created a distro with bin/mkdistro.sh and installed ext2.2. I can confirm that build version is displayed on the Web UI.

However, I don't like the response to request sent to "v2/admin/build-version":

curl 'http://localhost:11000/oozie/v2/admin/build-version'  
{"buildVersion":"5.0.0-beta1","buildInfo":"{build.time=2018.01.07-07:18:42GMT, vc.url=https:\/\/github.com\/apache\/oozie.git, build.user=asasvari, vc.revision=master@dde1284, build.version=5.0.0-beta1}"}

It is not a valid JSON.

I believe ObjectMapper should be used. For example:

        Map<String, Object> m = new LinkedHashMap<>();
        m.put("buildVersion", BuildInfo.BUILD_VERSION);
        m.put("buildInfo", BuildInfo.getBuildInfo());

        ObjectMapper objectMap = new ObjectMapper() ;
        try {
            System.out.println(objectMap.writeValueAsString(m));
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }

would return 

{"buildVersion":"build.version","buildInfo":{"build.time":"${build.time}","vc.url":"${vc.url}","build.user":"asasvari","vc.revision":"${vc.revision}","build.version":"5.0.0-beta1"}}
Thanks for pointing that issue out asasvari! I'm updating the patch to give back proper JSON

Thanks gezapeti. I tested your patch and curl 'http://localhost:11000/oozie/v2/admin/build-version' returned 

{"buildVersion":"5.0.0-beta1","buildInfo":"{\"build.time\":\"${build.time}\",\"vc.url\":\"${vc.url}\",\"build.user\":\"asasvari\",\"vc.revision\":\"${vc.revision}\",\"build.version\":\"5.0.0-beta1\"}"}

buildInfo is not a JSON object, it is a string. This is caused by json.put(JsonTags.BUILD_INFO, JSONValue.toJSONString(BuildInfo.getBuildInfo()));.; the JSON object converted to a string that is not what is needed here.

In BaseAdminServlet.doGet(), you could simply do something like json.put(JsonTags.BUILD_INFO, BuildInfo.getBuildInfo());}, which would return:

{"buildVersion":"5.0.0-beta1","buildInfo":{"build.version":"5.0.0-beta1","vc.url":"https:\/\/github.com\/apache\/oozie.git","vc.revision":"master@dde1284","build.time":"2018.01.08-16:15:03GMT","build.user":"asasvari"}}

(json.writeJSONString() knows how to serialize the embedded object in the JSONObject we pass to sendJsonResponse())

In Javascript, you can then parse this with with JSON.parse(). Escaped slashes are handled as expected; JSON.parse(response).buildInfo["vc.url"] returns "https://github.com/apache/oozie.git" (note: because the key contains a dot, the dot operator cannot be use to select "vc.url").
